text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

9.1	The Department of Economic and Social Affairs supports the development pillar of the United Nations Secretariat by fostering international cooperation for sustainable development for all. The Department’s responsibilities include: (a) providing substantive support to the United Nations bodies dealing with development issues, namely, the General Assembly, the Economic and Social Council and its functional commissions, and expert bodies; (b) monitoring and analysing development trends, prospects and policy issues globally; and (c) supporting the translation of policy frameworks developed in United Nations conferences and summits into policies and programmes at the country level and assisting Member States in building their national capacities. In doing so, the Department supports the implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the achievement of its Sustainable Development Goals through, among others, the regular programme of technical cooperation and United Nations Development Account projects. The mandate derives from the proposals put forward in the 1997 report of the Secretary-General entitled “Renewing the United Nations: a programme for reform” (A/51/950); in implementing the proposals, the General Assembly, in its resolution 52/220, noted the creation of the new Department of Economic and Social Affairs.

9.2	The Department forms the backbone of the normative and analytical support provided by the Secretariat to intergovernmental bodies and processes addressing the economic, social and environmental dimensions of sustainable development.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

9.3	The world continues to suffer setbacks in development progress, characterized by conflict, climate change, debt distress and high and rising inequalities. Countries in special situations, including the least developed countries, landlocked developing countries and small island developing States, remain particularly challenged. Middle-income countries still face challenges in achieving sustainable development.

9.4	Amid these challenges, a coherent and integrated approach in support of Member States is critical to accelerate progress in achieving the Sustainable Development Goals. The Department supports the commitments made by Member States through the political declarations of the Sustainable Development Goals Summit in 2019 and 2023, while being informed by the report of the Secretary-General on Our Common Agenda, adopted by the General Assembly in its resolution 76/6.

9.5	The Department continues to champion synergistic, future-focused approaches to sustainable development and approaches that address multiple, interlinked crises to improve the lives and livelihood of all people. This includes its work on climate action, sustainable infrastructure investment and risk-informed development cooperation.

9.6	The Department deploys foresight to anticipate economic, social and population trends. It generates, analyses and compiles a wide range of data and statistics to inform Member States and other stakeholders as they take stock of policy options to address global trends.
9.7	The Department identifies emerging trends and policy options for eradicating poverty, addressing inequalities and promoting opportunities for global progress.

9.8	In 2026, the Department will continue to support the delivery of the Pact for the Future, follow-up to the Antigua and Barbuda Agenda for Small Island Developing States and the 2026 United Nations Water Conference. The Department will strengthen the availability of critical social, demographic and economic data to inform transformative policy in crisis recovery. It will be a thought leader on sustainable development through analysis that accounts for the differentiated impacts of existing emerging trends, as well as policies and programmes, on the poorest and most vulnerable, and on women and girls. The Department will leverage workstreams on climate action, digital transformation, data accessibility, foresight and frontier issues analysis, as well as on financing for development, including reforms to the international financial architecture and international tax cooperation. It will provide strategic substantive support to the resident coordinator system and United Nations country teams, enhancing national implementation of internationally agreed objectives, with a focus on countries in Africa and countries in special situations. It will also support development cooperation with middle-income countries, in accordance with its mandate.

9.9	With regard to cooperation with other entities at the global, regional, national and local levels, the Department contributes to building multi-stakeholder partnerships and capacity development in thematic areas, including forests, natural resources, water, energy, climate, the ocean, transport, science and technology, and special concerns of small island developing States.

9.10	With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Department continues to support the quadrennial comprehensive policy review of operational activities for development of the United Nations system, in collaboration with United Nations system entities and the United Nations Sustainable Development Group. In collaboration with the Development Coordination Office, the Department facilitates structured engagement with resident coordinators strengthening delivery of capacity-building activities. These efforts assist in translating global norms and policy frameworks into national action towards the 2030 Agenda and other internationally agreed objectives. In addition, the Department, through the expanded Executive Committee on Economic and Social Affairs Plus, collaborates to ensure common approaches and synergies that support implementation of the 2030 Agenda, including on the voluntary national reviews and reporting of progress on the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals. Furthermore, the Department continues to work with various agencies and stakeholders to improve the policy analysis and knowledge products for Member States. To ensure coherence within and across topic areas, the Department continues to chair or co-chair inter-agency mechanisms for persons with disabilities, Indigenous Peoples, older persons and young people, legal identity, financing for development, statistics, and science, technology and innovation, among others. Moreover, the United Nations Economists’ Network continues to advance policy research on key current and emerging economic and financial issues, and their impact on sustainable development.
9.11	With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	Continued cooperation with policymakers and relevant national, regional and international stakeholders and entities on sustainable development issues in the various intergovernmental processes;
(b)	Continued availability of up-to-date and accurate information, data and trends for analytical products;
(c)	Governments and other relevant stakeholders continue to collaborate in undertaking the proposed programme activities with the necessary capacity and resources.

9.12	The Department integrates a gender perspective into its normative and analytical work and its support for intergovernmental bodies, including in its programme activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. It continues to apply gender analysis in its work and highlight issues related to gender equality in the substantive documentation and deliberations of intergovernmental bodies, as appropriate.

9.13	In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the Department promotes inclusive sustainable development for all, including persons with disabilities, and realizes the promise of the 2030 Agenda to leave no one behind. As secretariat to the Conference of States Parties to the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, the Department facilitates global dialogue to address existing gaps in translating the international commitments to persons with disabilities into development policies, programming and practices at the national and international levels. This includes the compilation and analysis of disability data and the highlighting of best practices in fostering more accessible and disability-inclusive societies.

children.text: Evaluation activities
9.16	An evaluation conducted by the Department on its information and communications technology (ICT) governance and services, completed in 2024, has guided the proposed programme plan for 2026.

9.17	In response to the results of the evaluation referenced above, the Department will, in 2026, identify additional ways to optimize resources for ICT to better meet the expectations of Member States and will promote innovation and enhance data and digital capabilities.
9.18	An evaluation to be conducted by the Department on cross-cutting or thematic topics across subprogrammes, in line with its 2024–2026 evaluation plan, is planned for 2026.
Programme of work
Subprogramme 1 – Intergovernmental support and coordination for sustainable development
Objective

9.19	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to advance the roles of the General Assembly, the Economic and Social Council and the high-level political forum on sustainable development in the integrated implementation of and follow-up to the 2030 Agenda and the outcomes of other United Nations conferences and summits in the economic, social, environmental and related fields.
Strategy

9.20	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will continue to support the Economic and Social Council and the high-level political forum on sustainable development in the promotion and review of the integrated implementation of the 2030 Agenda and related international commitments within the context of the follow-up to the 2023 political declaration adopted at the high-level political forum convened under the auspices of the General Assembly and the 2024 ministerial declaration of the high-level political forum. Specifically, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Provide evidence-based analysis and advice to the Council by: (i) facilitating policy dialogue and the formulation of policy recommendations; (ii) monitoring and leveraging the work of its subsidiary bodies and United Nations system entities; (iii) identifying new and emerging issues having an impact on achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals; and (iv) reinforcing the links between policy discussions and reviews and national sustainable development efforts;

(b)	Support the high-level political forum on sustainable development in the follow-up to and implementation of the 2030 Agenda by: (i) facilitating the progress review, policy dialogue and developing policy recommendations for the accelerated achievement of the 2030 Agenda, including through enhanced advocacy and communication efforts; (ii) assisting countries in preparing evidence-based, inclusive and analytical voluntary national reviews of their implementation of the 2030 Agenda; and (iii) engaging United Nations country teams, other subprogrammes of the Department and United Nations system entities in supporting the review process;
(c)	Provide substantive support, upon request, to policy discussions and negotiations of the General Assembly, notably its Second Committee (economic and financial issues);

(d)	Provide evidence and analysis for Member States to review and guide the operational activities of the United Nations development system based on mandates from the General Assembly’s 2024 quadrennial comprehensive policy review of the operational activities for development of the United Nations system, including through the redesigned quadrennial comprehensive review monitoring and reporting framework, in collaboration with United Nations system entities;

(e)	Support the resident coordinator system in guiding United Nations country teams in assisting countries in conducting voluntary national reviews and in enabling the country teams to provide coordinated assessment of the implementation of the quadrennial comprehensive policy review, in coordination with the Development Coordination Office;

(f)	Support the work of the Ad Hoc Advisory Group on Haiti in providing advice on the long-term development strategy of the country, promoting socioeconomic recovery, reconstruction and sustainability and encouraging international support, based on Haiti’s national development priorities;

(g)	Provide analysis, evidence and recommendations on effective, people-centred and gender-sensitive approaches to address the multiple and interlinked global crises and accelerate the implementation of the 2030 Agenda, including addressing the impacts of crises on women and people in vulnerable situations, ensuring that no one is left behind;

(h)	Support the engagement of non-governmental organizations (NGOs) in the work of the Council and the participation of major groups and other stakeholders in relevant intergovernmental processes, including the high-level political forum on sustainable development;

(i)	Strengthen the engagement of young people in the work of the United Nations by improving the annual Council youth forum, in cooperation with the United Nations Youth Office and subprogramme 2 and facilitating the participation of youth speakers in other Council segments, forums, special meetings and the high-level political forum on sustainable development.
9.21	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Enhanced policy and operational guidance by the General Assembly and the Economic and Social Council on the implementation of the 2030 Agenda at the global, regional and country levels;

(b)	A strengthened Council and high-level political forum on sustainable development, which will include improved understanding of the role of the Council as a principal Charter body for the coordinated and integrated implementation of the 2030 Agenda and that of the high-level political forum for more effective follow-up and review of the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals;

(c)	Better understanding among Member States, United Nations system organizations and other stakeholders of the multiple and interlinked global crises affecting implementation of the 2030 Agenda, and of policy options and practical measures for addressing the global crises, while accelerating progress towards the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals and the implementation of the Pact for the Future, and better coordination and coherence in the global response to ongoing crises;

(d)	Progress at the country level towards realizing the Sustainable Development Goals, including in countries presenting voluntary national reviews at the high-level political forum on sustainable development;

(e)	Effective, efficient and coordinated United Nations development system support towards implementing the 2030 Agenda and responding to crises, including support for voluntary national reviews, as well as improved and clearer guidance from Member States to the United Nations development system;
(f) 	Increased and coordinated international support for Haiti’s long-term development, stability and sustainable development;
(g)	The voice of young people being heard at deliberations through the Council’s youth forum;

(h)	Improved engagement of NGOs in the work of the United Nations through support for the Committee on Non-Governmental Organizations, including through the integrated civil society organization system;
(i)	Increased participation of major groups and other stakeholders in the work of the high-level political forum on sustainable development, as mandated in General Assembly resolution 67/290.
Programme performance in 2024
Advancing the implementation of the 2030 Agenda through effective multilateral solutions

9.22	The subprogramme supported the Economic and Social Council in leveraging the technical expertise and policy recommendations of its subsidiary bodies and the work of the United Nations system for informed policy-making through the Council’s 2024 coordination and management segments. The subprogramme assisted Member States in reaching consensus on the ministerial declaration of the 2024 high-level segment of the Council and the high-level political forum on sustainable development under the auspices of the Council, and on the 2024 quadrennial comprehensive policy review resolution, and facilitated implementation of the operational activities segment. The Council, through the subprogramme’s support, brings in young people, civil society and other stakeholders to engage with Member States to advance the 2030 Agenda.

children.text: Result 3: accelerated achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals through an effective preparatory process for voluntary national reviews – Proposed programme plan for 2026

9.28	Implementing the commitments of the 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals requires greater cooperation at all levels. To better assess the implementation and progress at the national and subnational levels and to facilitate the sharing of experiences, successes, challenges and lessons learned, the subprogramme supports the preparations and presentations of inclusive voluntary national reviews, including organizing annual workshops.
Lessons learned and planned change

9.29	The lesson for the subprogramme was the need to facilitate better the connection between the United Nations country teams and Member States during the voluntary national reviews. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will work closely with the Development Coordination Office to strengthen coherence in the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals at the national level.

children.text: Subprogramme 2 – Inclusive social development
Objective

9.32	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to advance policies for the eradication of poverty, the reduction in inequality and the achievement of greater social inclusion and well-being for all.
Strategy
9.33	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:
(a)	Conduct evidence-based research and analysis, including on Indigenous Peoples, persons with disabilities, older persons and young people;

(b)	Monitor national and global socioeconomic trends to identify emerging issues and assess their implications for social policy at the national and international levels, which will help Member States to make progress towards achieving Sustainable Development Goals 1 to 11 and 16;

(c)	Provide substantive support for intergovernmental dialogue and processes, including the sessions of the Commission for Social Development, the Permanent Forum on Indigenous Issues, the Conference of States Parties to the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, the Economic and Social Council and the General Assembly;

(d)	Provide analyses, technical advice and capacity development to requesting countries in partnership with resident coordinators and United Nations entities, including through the use of sport as an enabler of development and peace, as foreseen in the preamble of the 2030 Agenda. The subprogramme’s analytical work will include a focus on reducing inequality, insecurity and strengthening social protection systems, and it will advance the situation of vulnerable segments of the population and engage more closely with United Nations country teams to enhance action at the national level;

(e)	Support Member States on issues related to shocks and recovery by promoting socially inclusive policy responses designed to eradicate poverty, reduce inequalities and protect the most vulnerable populations.
9.34	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Enhanced knowledge and awareness of Member States to ensure that no one is left behind;
(b)	Recognition by Member States of specific social development issues as a basis for action at the national level;
(c)	Increased capacity of Member States to effectively implement the social dimension of the 2030 Agenda;
(d)	Progress of Member States in achieving more resilient and inclusive societies, placing the world back on track to implementing the 2030 Agenda.
Programme performance in 2024
Increased capacity and awareness of Member States to ratify and implement the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities

9.35	More than 1.3 billion people worldwide live with disabilities. However, persistent gaps remain between persons with disabilities and persons without disabilities, including women and girls with disabilities. Advancing and promoting disability inclusion across all fronts is pivotal in the realization of the Sustainable Development Goals. The subprogramme conducted research, provided policy recommendations to address the gaps and organized capacity-building and awareness-raising workshops for government officials at the national and local levels and representatives of persons with disabilities, to increase capacity and awareness on the ratification and implementation of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. For example, the subprogramme published the Disability and Development Report 2024, in which good practices and recommended action in accessibility and inclusion for the effective implementation of the Convention were identified.

children.text: Result 3: accelerated social development through the Second World Summit for Social Development – Proposed programme plan for 2026

9.41	Since the adoption of the Copenhagen Declaration on Social Development and the Programme of Action in 1995, Member States have expressed concern that progress towards full implementation has been slow and uneven, and decided to convene the Second World Summit for Social Development to review the gaps and reaffirm commitments. The subprogramme will support the Summit and its preparatory process by developing analytical outputs, facilitating intergovernmental negotiations and coordinating inter-agency collaboration.
Lessons learned and planned change

9.42	The lesson for the subprogramme was that previous experience and knowledge for holding large conferences from across the United Nations system could better inform and strengthen the preparatory process for the Summit. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will incorporate feedback from other United Nations entities and Member States through targeted consultations and regular dialogue, ensuring effective support for Member States in their engagement and negotiations.

children.text: Subprogramme 3 – Sustainable development
Objective

9.45	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to accelerate the implementation of the 2030 Agenda, including the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals and their targets and commitments, through increased engagement of Member States and other stakeholders.
Strategy
9.46	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:
(a)	Prepare analytical reports and assessments, maintain online databases and organize thematic expert meetings and conferences on specific Sustainable Development Goals and their interlinkages;

(b)	Organize, in the lead up to the high-level political forum on sustainable development expert group meetings and conferences for Member States, on the themes of the forum and Sustainable Development Goals that are under review;

(c)	Play a central role in inter-agency coordination mechanisms on water, energy, small island developing States, oceans and transport and in the area of science, technology and innovation, and through its long-standing cooperation with specific agencies on issues such as climate change and partnership-building for sustainable development;

(d)	Coordinate the work of the Technology Facilitation Mechanism, including the multi-stakeholder forum on science, technology and innovation for the Sustainable Development Goals and the online platform on existing science, technology and innovation initiatives (2030 Connect);

(e)	Convene special events in connection with the high-level political forum on sustainable development, including the Sustainable Development Goals business forum and the local and regional governments forum, enabling the sharing of lessons learned and good practices among Member States and stakeholders in the development arena;

(f)	Organize, in coordination with the regional commissions, resident coordinator offices and United Nations country teams, as applicable, capacity-building activities at the global, regional and national levels on the above topics.
9.47	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	Increased knowledge of Member States and stakeholders of the 2030 Agenda and its Sustainable Development Goals, including for their deliberations during the high-level political forum on sustainable development and other related forums, and for the development of related national policies and programmes;
(b)	Increased use of science and technology to leverage their full potential in the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals by Member States and other stakeholders;

(c)	Increased integration of Sustainable Development Goals into inclusive national planning processes, policies and strategies, and increased action and initiatives taken by Member States and other stakeholders to accelerate the implementation of the 2030 Agenda.
Programme performance in 2024
Advancing the implementation of the United Nations Decade of Sustainable Transport (2026–2035)

9.48	The General Assembly, in its resolution 78/148, called for a United Nations Decade of Sustainable Transport to commence in 2026 and requested an associated implementation plan. The subprogramme launched the preparations for the Decade and its implementation plan through consultations with Member States, civil society, academia and multilateral development banks. The dialogue provided opportunities and tools for intergraded policymaking on sustainable transport.

9.54	Action to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals, including Goal 6 on water and sanitation, ensuring the interlinkages and co-benefits among them, should remain a priority. The subprogramme will ensure the successful planning and organization of the 2026 United Nations Water Conference to advance Goal 6 realization and enable Member States to achieve the Goals and implement the 2030 Agenda as a whole.
Lessons learned and planned change

9.55	The lesson for the subprogramme was that robust stakeholder participation was crucial to the success of the 2023 United Nations Water Conference. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will build on the momentum generated, strengthen stakeholder engagement, enhance advocacy and analytical work, and support Member States in accelerating the achievement of the water and sanitation-related Sustainable Development Goals, leaving no one behind.

children.text: Subprogramme 4 – Statistics
Objective

9.58	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to strengthen the capacity of Member States with regard to the production and use of high-quality, timely, disaggregated, open data and national statistics and geospatial information as a basis on which to inform policy and decision-making for the 2030 Agenda and for other United Nations policy agendas and to review progress at the national and international levels.
Strategy
9.59	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Develop, disseminate and support the implementation by Member States of statistical and geospatial information frameworks, standards and methods, especially those related to the Sustainable Development Goals, the Integrated Geospatial Information Framework and other new emerging policy issues;

(b)	Provide technical assistance and advice to Member States through training on the modernization of statistical information systems, the Integrated Geospatial Information Framework, the use of big data, artificial intelligence and data science, population data systems, environmental-economic accounting, quality assurance, survey instruments and citizen data, to fill data gaps and leave no one excluded from decision-making and policies that affect them;

(c)	Facilitate and expand the coordination and coherence of international statistical and geospatial information programmes and activities by promoting the availability, accessibility and application of geospatial information, including the standardization of geographical names, and better integration of statistical and geospatial information;

(d)	Cooperate with the resident coordinator system and United Nations country teams in data and statistical activities and their interaction with the global statistical community, including through the Global Network of Data Officers and Statisticians; cooperate closely with other international organizations and establish partnerships with civil society organizations, academia and private sector data providers, including through the Collaborative on Citizen Data;

(e)	Collect, compile and disseminate global statistical information and data in the areas of economic, social, demographic and environmental statistics, including the Sustainable Development Goals indicators, through the use of technology and interoperability standards, such as the Statistical Data and Metadata Exchange;

(f)	Issue flagship data publications, maintain databases and data platforms and continue to modernize UNdata as a United Nations system-wide portal, and support the development of open data hubs and labs to showcase innovative uses of data, artificial intelligence and data science, and enhance the visualization of data and metadata;

(g)	Collect information from Member States on the implementation of the Integrated Geospatial Information Framework and the Medellín Framework for Action on Data for Sustainable Development relating to the 2030 Agenda, including on financing needs in the specific areas included in the Framework, under the guidance of the High-level Group for Partnership, Coordination and Capacity-Building for Statistics for the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and in collaboration with issue partners;

(h)	Develop and share guidance and information on initiatives, tools and best practices to help national statistics systems to continue to operate and respond to the new specific data needs to address and mitigate the impact of global crises on societies, advance responsible, equitable and interoperable data governance approaches, and address issues of open and timely access to critical data needed by Governments and all sectors of society to accelerate the implementation of the 2030 Agenda.
9.60	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Enhanced quality, availability and access to policy-relevant statistical and geospatial information;

(b)	Increased production and dissemination by Member States of better data and national statistics and geospatial information that are comparable and in line with the adopted international frameworks and standards, and provision of enhanced and open access to them;
(c)	Enhanced coherence and more effective functioning and transformation of the global statistical and geospatial information systems;
(d)	Increased statistical and geospatial information capacity of Member States and the United Nations system.
Programme performance in 2024
Digital technologies and capacity-building drove successful population and housing census implementation in the 2020 round

9.61	The population and housing census provides detailed, reliable and periodical statistics for small areas and population groups essential for evidence-based decision-making, facilitating equitable resource allocation, public administration and policymaking. Sixty-nine countries and areas, covering 27 per cent of the world’s population, conducted population and housing censuses (2022 to 2024), including those postponed from 2020 and 2021 owing to the COVID-19 pandemic. By the end of the 2020 census round in December 2024, 204 countries and areas had conducted a census. The subprogramme supported those censuses through organizing regional workshops, providing ad hoc technical assistance and emphasizing the use of digital technologies, including georeferencing and the integration of administrative data to enhance efficiency and data quality. Countries reported achievements in these areas such as successful budget management and timely data dissemination. Other achievements included increased use of census data for Sustainable Development Goals monitoring, geocoded census results and the adoption of international standards. The 2020 census round saw advancements in technology, methodology and operational efficiency, producing high-quality data for evidence-based policymaking and planning.
9.62	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 9.II).
Figure 9.II – Performance measure: number of countries and areas that conducted a census (cumulative)
Planned results for 2026
Result 1: accelerated implementation of the Integrated Geospatial Information Framework – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

9.63	The subprogramme’s work contributed to the inclusive engagement and development of 15 country-level action plans based on the Integrated Geospatial Information Management Framework, which met the planned target.
9.64	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 9.III).
Figure 9.III – Performance measure: number of countries that developed action plans based on the Integrated Geospatial Information Framework (cumulative)
Result 2: UNdata modernization: a single entry point for authoritative statistical data from the United Nations system – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

9.65	The subprogramme’s work contributed to an average of 35,939 UNdata user sessions per month, which did not meet the planned target of 38,000. The target was not met owing to the decline in legacy traffic, which was offset in part by an increase in traffic to the new UNdata interface, launched in September 2023.
9.66	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 9.IV).
Figure 9.IV – Performance measure: average number of UNdata user sessions per month
Result 3: improved global capacity for evidence-based Sustainable Development Goals progress monitoring – Proposed programme plan for 2026

9.67	In the 2030 Agenda, the critical role of high-quality, accessible, timely and reliable data for measuring progress towards achieving the Sustainable Development Goals is emphasized. National statistical capacity is fundamental for producing and disseminating indicators of the Goals, enabling evidence-based decision-making. The subprogramme, in collaboration with custodian agencies, has supported national statistical offices through technical assistance, methodological guidance and training activities, leading to a nine-fold increase in data availability in the global indicator database, with data records rising from 330,000 in 2016 to 2.9 million by 2024. The number of tier I indicators – those with good data coverage regularly produced for at least 50 per cent of relevant countries – rose from 82 in 2016 to 161 in 2024, demonstrating improved global capacity for evidence-based progress monitoring.
Lessons learned and planned change

9.68	The lesson for the subprogramme was that strengthening national statistical capacity required a comprehensive approach combining technical training, methodological support and sustained engagement with national statistical offices. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will provide targeted technical assistance, develop e-learning platforms for Sustainable Development Goals monitoring, implement standardized data-collection tools and support countries in adopting international statistical standards for reporting on the Goals.
9.69	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 9.V).
Figure 9.V – Performance measure: number of tier I indicators in the global Sustainable Development Goals indicator database (cumulative)

children.text: Subprogramme 5 – Population
Objective

9.71	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to improve knowledge of global population trends, advance an evidence-based understanding of interaction between population change and sustainable development among policymakers and the public, and strengthen the international community’s capacity to effectively address current and emerging population issues and integrate the population dimension into the international development agenda.
Strategy
9.72	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Prepare studies on population growth, population ageing, migration, urbanization, fertility, family planning, mortality and other aspects of population in relation to sustainable development using population estimates and projections, the analysis of demographic trends and the evaluation of population policies;

(b)	Produce comprehensive global data sets on selected topics, as well as reports to highlight these topics and related data, and an annual report on a selected major demographic topic. Data sets will include aggregated results for groups of countries in special situations;
(c)	Provide capacity development on population data and analysis to requesting countries and to United Nations country teams;

(d)	Provide substantive support to United Nations intergovernmental bodies, in particular the Commission on Population and Development, including by preparing reports and convening expert meetings and panels;

(e)	Assist Governments in assessing progress made in implementing the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development held in 1994, focusing on the global monitoring of Sustainable Development Goals indicators on reproductive health, international migration, child and maternal mortality and population ageing, often in partnership with other entities of the United Nations system;

(f)	Improve the United Nations estimates and projections of the global population and study the interaction of COVID-19 and other crises with demographic phenomena, including mortality, population ageing, fertility and family planning and international migration, and including these analyses, as appropriate, in publications and technical materials.
9.73	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Improved access to data and reports on population matters for Governments and other users and increased use of the subprogramme’s data and findings in the work of stakeholders;

(b)	Increased awareness of population trends and their relationship to sustainable development through accurate data and policy-relevant reports, benefiting Member States and other stakeholders in policy and development planning;
(c)	Advancement in the international community’s use of scientifically grounded information about the demographic impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic and other crises.
Programme performance in 2024
Improved monitoring of progress towards achieving safe, orderly and regular migration

9.74	In the Progress Declaration of the International Migration Review Forum in May 2022, Member States requested the Secretary-General to propose a limited set of indicators to review progress related to the implementation of the Global Compact for Safe, Orderly and Regular Migration, drawing on the Sustainable Development Goals indicator framework and other frameworks, as well as a comprehensive strategy for improving disaggregated migration data. The subprogramme co-led a workstream established by the United Nations Network on Migration that undertook consultations with Member States and stakeholders, including regional consultations in 2023, global consultations in 2024 and online surveys. The proposed indicators, consisting of 27 core and 83 additional indicators, are a voluntary tool for Member States to conduct inclusive progress reviews on the implementation of the Global Compact.
9.75	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 9.17).
Table 9.17 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Member States requested a limited set of indicators for monitoring the implementation of the Global Compact for Safe, Orderly and Regular Migration
Member States and stakeholders engaged in consultations and online surveys on the indicator framework
Member States and stakeholders have access to the new voluntary indicator framework to monitor progress made in the implementation of the Global Compact

children.text: Result 3: enhanced online tools for demographic analysis, projection and visualization – Proposed programme plan for 2026

9.80	World Population Prospects and related guidance on producing population projections are fundamental resources for Member States. The subprogramme has increased the reproducibility of the estimates and projections and the transparency of the metadata provided in the last two editions of World Population Prospects.
Lessons learned and planned change

9.81	The lesson for the subprogramme was that the development of user-friendly online tools for countries to produce demographic analyses and population projections using new country data and compare these to results from World Population Prospects would help to harmonize national and international population estimates and projections. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will leverage and expand online platforms to enhance the dissemination and use of the 2026 edition of World Population Prospects.
9.82	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 9.19).

children.text: Subprogramme 6 – Economic analysis and policy
Objective

9.84	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to strengthen national capacities and international policy coordination for identifying and managing short-term macroeconomic risks, to shape medium- and long-term socioeconomic policies for development and to accelerate sustainable development, especially of least developed countries, small island developing States and other countries in special situations.
Strategy
9.85	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	At the national, regional and global levels, monitor and forecast the macroeconomic situation, focusing on countries in special situations, including the least developed countries, and support Member States in the formulation of global, regional and national policies through expert group meetings, country-level empirical evidence analysis and background studies on short- and long-term economic development thematic issues;

(b)	Broaden the scope of economic forecasting and simulation tools to assess policy trade-offs in promoting economic growth, while reducing poverty and inequality and enhancing environmental sustainability, in line with the 2030 Agenda;

(c)	Support the Committee for Development Policy and provide analytical input to the intergovernmental processes related to the least developed countries, as well as to the annual themes of meetings of the Economic and Social Council and of the high-level political forum on sustainable development;

(d)	Design and implement capacity development activities for a range of countries, including for graduating and recently graduated least developed countries, enhancing capacity for economic planning monitoring and policymaking;

(e)	Examine rapid technological change, noting both its constructive and disruptive potential and identifying the strategies and policies necessary to harness its positive potential for achieving sustainable development, while mitigating its possible negative effects;
(f)	Provide policy guidance and recommendations on selected topics to Member States for recovery from recurrent shocks, crises and challenges, building on the subprogramme’s analytical work;

(g)	Provide analytical input and customized online resources to the resident coordinator system for supporting Member States and for the preparation of common country analyses and United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Frameworks, and other pertinent topics;

(h)	Deliver the substantive leadership and coordination of the United Nations Economists’ Network, bringing together United Nations system economists to share perspectives from the local, national, regional and global levels;

(i)	Maintain the global economic outlook database, the least developed country criteria database, the Support Measures Portal for Least Developed Countries on international support measures and other online resources available to policymakers and other national and international stakeholders.

(j)	Advance the formulation of a specific response plan, aimed at better addressing the multidimensional nature of sustainable development and facilitating sustainable development cooperation and coordinated and inclusive support to middle-income countries based on their specific challenges and diverse needs.
9.86	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	Greater articulation of short-term macroeconomic stability with long-term development goals, while advancing the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals, through the improved integration of economic, social and environmental priorities into national development plans and strategies;

(b)	Improved awareness among Member States of the multilateral efforts and economic policy options necessary for a sustainable recovery from recurrent shocks, crises and challenges, consistent with the 2030 Agenda;
(c)	Improved information basis for the Committee for Development Policy and the Economic and Social Council when assessing and recommending least developed countries for graduation;

(d)	Enhanced awareness and knowledge of Member States and the international community of the development trajectory of the least developed countries, their risks and challenges and the specific support options;

(e)	Increased capacity of Member States to effectively use international support measures, prepare for graduation from the least developed country category and ensure the stability of their development progress and the realization of the 2030 Agenda;

(f)	Enhanced collaboration, coordination and efficacy of the United Nations development system, which will provide a more coherent cooperation framework towards the implementation of the 2030 Agenda and bolster sustainable development at the country level.
Programme performance in 2024
Strengthened policy analysis and recommendations on national and global action to build resilience

9.87	In recent years, converging shocks, crises and challenges that produce long-lasting impacts on social development have risen. National action and international collaboration that are mutually complementary are essential for advancing social development amid converging crises. The subprogramme led the preparation of the World Social Report 2024: Social Development in Times of Converging Crises: A Call for Global Action, which highlighted how both national efforts and international action need to evolve to advance social development with evidence-based policy analysis and recommendations.
9.88	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 9.21).
Table 9.21 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Member states and other stakeholders have enhanced understanding of recurrent crises and their impact on Sustainable Development Goals as reflected in policy discussions
Intergovernmental dialogue focused on an in-depth analysis in specialized areas with proposed policy options

Member States and other stakeholders have access to policy options for both national and collective action presented in the World Social Report 2024, launched on the International Day for the Eradication of Poverty, to enhance resilience in times of converging crises

The target was not met because, at Member States’ request, additional capacity-building events were organized to improve their knowledge of existing tools and ability to link different simulation tools for policy formulation.

Result 3: increased engagement and use of analytical products for evidence-based policymaking – Proposed programme plan for 2026

9.93	Access to analytical products is important for evidence-based policymaking. The subprogramme has taken steps to further disseminate its analytical products and engage stakeholders through targeted efforts. Findings and policy options have been presented and discussed with representatives and experts from Member States, international organizations, academia, NGOs and civil society.
Lessons learned and planned change

9.94	The lesson for the subprogramme was that this more holistic and targeted approach to the delivery of analytical products helped to inform evidence-based policies. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will assess its stakeholder engagement and areas requiring improvement to ensure that the products meet users’ needs.

children.text: Subprogramme 7 – Public institutions and digital government
Objective

9.97	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to advance effective, accountable and inclusive governance and public institutions for sustainable development, including through innovation, digital government and digital transformation.
Strategy
9.98	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Service the Committee of Experts on Public Administration by organizing expert meetings and preparing analytical papers and technical guidelines to operationalize the principles of effective governance for sustainable development, developed by the Committee and endorsed by the Economic and Social Council in 2018, together with all relevant stakeholders;

(b)	Promote policy guidance on innovation, digital government and digital transformation, including the use of artificial intelligence, for the Sustainable Development Goals through the United Nations E-Government Survey, monitor global developments on institutional dimensions covered by Goals 16 and 17 and review national institutional arrangements for the achievement of the Goals, with a specific focus on countries in special situations, and in direct support of the follow-up on and review of the 2030 Agenda;

(c)	Foster policy dialogue and advocacy for the implementation of the outcomes of the World Summit on the Information Society and facilitate the implementation of and follow-up on its assigned action lines, namely, C1 (the role of Governments and all stakeholders in the promotion of ICT for development), C7 (ICT applications: benefits in all aspects of life (e-government)) and C11 (international and regional cooperation);

(d)	Facilitate multi-stakeholder policy dialogue on Internet governance, including discussion of public policy issues related to key elements of Internet governance, such as data governance, digital inclusion and data protection (General Assembly resolution 70/125, para. 63), and shape policy decisions at the global, national and local levels by supporting the annual meeting of the Internet Governance Forum and intersessional activities;

(e)	Expand capacity development to respond to Member States’ requests for technical cooperation on strengthening their governance, public institutions and human resources capacities in alignment with the decade of action and delivery for sustainable development, including through partnerships with regional commissions and the resident coordinator system and increased efforts to support international peer exchanges on effective governance for sustainable development;

(f)	Expand work on equipping the public sector workforce with the capacities to realize the 2030 Agenda and the Pact for the Future, which includes developing and piloting new methodologies on leadership and changing mindsets, institutional arrangements for policy coherence, transparency and integrity in the public service, strategic foresight, digital government and data governance, and innovation for public service delivery, with an emphasis on countries in special situations, in collaboration with the resident coordinator system;

(g)	Strengthen the capacity of Member States to promote innovation in public governance through follow-up mechanisms to the United Nations Public Service Day Awards Ceremony and Forum, such as peer-to-peer learning for the transfer and adaptation of innovative practices, including on gender-sensitive analysis, and through the United Nations Public Administration Network;

(h)	Support supreme audit institutions on auditing Sustainable Development Goals achievement by providing analytical work, expert advice, technical assistance and capacity-building, on the basis of existing demand for support by groups of the International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions;
(i)	Promote and leverage public governance innovative practices and digital government strategies action plans and road maps.
9.99	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	Enhanced awareness of emerging governance and public administration issues at the national and subnational levels and countries contextualizing institutional aspects of their voluntary national reviews so that Member States can develop their capacities to promote effective governance for sustainable development in a dynamic international context;
(b)	Increased capacities of Member States to build effective, accountable and inclusive institutions at all levels to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals and deliver on the Pact for the Future;

(c)	Increased capacity of Member States in designing and implementing effective and inclusive digital government policies, strategies and services to improve people’s lives at all levels of government;

(d)	Improved capacities of public servants to deliver services to people in areas such as health and education, justice, social protection and employment, focusing on professionalization of the public sector workforce, an ethical, responsive and ICT-enabled public administration and progress towards gender equality in the public sector;
(e)	Adjustments by Member States at the structural, organizational and programme levels to accelerate Sustainable Development Goals delivery;
(f)	Adoption of digital government strategies to build resilient societies and close digital divides.
Programme performance in 2024
Adoption of road maps and action plans for transformational change in governance

9.100	Strategic foresight, shifting mindsets and data governance are crucial in pursuing transformational change for improved planning and achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals. The subprogramme has designed and implemented its capacity development work by addressing strategic foresight, behavioural science and data governance in an integrated manner and has supported Member States through the curriculum on governance for the Goals, a set of training of trainers’ toolkits and a webinar series. By adopting this approach, the subprogramme has enabled Member States to become more resilient and adopt instruments that allow them to anticipate, prepare, respond and adapt to increasingly complex new realities.
9.101	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 9.24).
Table 9.24 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Public officials increased awareness of a forward-thinking culture, enabling transformational change in governance to thrive
Public officials have enhanced knowledge and competencies needed for new solutions to accelerate progress on the Sustainable Development Goals
Public officials adopted road maps and action plans for foresight-informed decision-making on national priorities and agendas

Result 1: enhanced innovation and digital government transformation for effective and inclusive public service delivery – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

children.text: Result 3: efficient and resilient response to future challenges and opportunities to accelerate sustainable development – Proposed programme plan for 2026

9.106	Establishing anticipatory governance frameworks for long-term strategic planning while cultivating a foresight-driven organizational culture allows governments to proactively address present and future opportunities and risks. The subprogramme has provided policy advice and capacity development support in systems thinking, strategic foresight and changing mindsets, enhancing the knowledge of policymakers, including on promoting the presence and leadership of women within public institutions.
Lessons learned and planned change

9.107	The lesson for the subprogramme was the need for a whole-of-government and whole-of-society approach and a shift in mindsets towards strategic foresight, to address multiple crises and adapt to rapid changes. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will strengthen its capacity development work on implementing a holistic approach to anticipatory governance.

children.text: Subprogramme 8 – Sustainable forest management
Objective

9.110	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to ensure the effective implementation of sustainable management of all types of forests at all levels in accordance with the United Nations strategic plan for forests 2017–2030.
Strategy
9.111	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Support the intergovernmental forest policy dialogue through the United Nations Forum on Forests, in accordance with the strategic plan, the quadrennial programme of work (2025–2028) and the outcomes of the nineteenth session of the Forum, including the 2024 midterm review of the effectiveness of the international arrangement on forests, and coordinate the Forum’s input to the high-level political forum on sustainable development;
(b)	Advance coordination and cooperation with relevant United Nations entities, member organizations of the Collaborative Partnership on Forests and other stakeholders;

(c)	Develop the online clearinghouse of the Global Forest Financing Facilitation Network and assist countries and partners in designing forest financing strategies, facilitating access to financing and assisting Member States in mobilizing resources for sustainable forest management;

(d)	Place an emphasis on the special needs and circumstances of Africa, the least developed countries, countries with low forest cover, countries with high forest cover, countries with medium forest cover and low deforestation and small island developing States, as well as countries with economies in transition (Economic and Social Council resolution 2017/4, para. 63);

(e)	Advance the implementation of the United Nations strategic plan for forests 2017–2030, including through assisting countries in developing a robust national reporting format for the submission of national reports to the United Nations Forum on Forests, preparing the second global forest goals report and implementation of strategic plan’s communication and outreach strategy;

(f)	Support common country analyses, which inform the United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework, thereby providing resident coordinators with the tools to tailor their responses to countries’ specific needs and priorities and to support the implementation of the 2030 Agenda, including through national implementation of sustainable forest management;

(g)	Support Member States, as appropriate, on issues related to sustainable forest management, through its normative work, technical assistance and capacity-building activities, including the international policy dialogue on the integration of sustainable forest management into decision-making processes concerning land use planning and development, in line with United Nations Forum on Forests’ resolutions.
9.112	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	Strengthened political commitment and action for sustainable forest management, leading to increased contributions by forests to Sustainable Development Goals achievement, including on climate change, biodiversity, land and greater integration of forests into national sustainable development plans and poverty reduction strategies;

(b)	Improved capacity of eligible countries to mobilize and gain access to financing for sustainable forest management, and improved information on and access to existing and emerging multilateral and other funding sources and data;
(c)	Member States’ progress towards achieving the global forest goals and the forest-related Sustainable Development Goals;

(d)	Increased awareness among Member States of the benefits of forests based on the 2026 theme of the International Day of Forests, and on highlighting the interdependent role of forests in enabling the world to meet the Sustainable Development Goals that will be reviewed during the 2026 high-level political forum on sustainable development.
Programme performance in 2024
Member States track progress on implementation of the United Nations strategic plan for forests

9.113	Comprehensive forest monitoring, assessment and reporting is essential for informed and evidence-based decision-making, while systematic data are critical for understanding how forests contribute to livelihoods, poverty reduction, health and well-being, and sustainable development. Following workshops to strengthen national capacities to identify data sources and systematic data collection in 2023, the subprogramme developed a road map and timeline for the second national reporting cycle in 2024 and an online reporting platform to streamline the national reporting process. Member States and partners will use this platform for their voluntary national reports and track progress in implementing the United Nations strategic plan for forests 2017–2030. The findings from this second round of national reporting will contribute to the second Global Forest Goals Report, to be published in May 2026.
9.114	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 9.28).
Table 9.28 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Member States have enhanced capacity to create and/or improve existing monitoring and reporting mechanisms for tracking sustainable forest management
Member States used the online reporting format tool to produce national reports on progress made in the implementation of the United Nations strategic plan for forests 2017–2030

children.text: Result 3: advancement of the Sustainable Development Goals through the United Nations strategic plan for forests 2017–2030 – Proposed programme plan for 2026

9.119	The programme of work for the period 2025–2028 of the United Nations Forum on Forests includes fundamental interlinkages between global forest goals and the Sustainable Development Goals. The subprogramme assisted countries in delivering consistent messages on the interlinkages in line with national priorities and relevant mandates.
Lessons learned and planned change

9.120	The lesson for the subprogramme was that an in-depth analysis of international forest related developments and their interlinkages was necessary to inform advancement of the implementation of the United Nations strategic plan for forests 2017–2030. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will conduct further analytical work on these interlinkages to accelerate the achievement of the Goals, minimize duplication and increase complementarity of the globally agreed forest related goals, targets and commitments, and continue to develop knowledge-promoting materials in collaboration with the Collaborative Partnership on Forests.

Member States and forest stakeholders accelerate action on forests, addressing climate change, biodiversity loss and sustainable development

Member States and forest stakeholders build political momentum on forests and their contributions to sustainable development through the adoption of a resolution at the twenty-first session of the United Nations Forum on Forests

children.text: Subprogramme 9 – Financing for sustainable development
Objective

9.123	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to advance the follow-up on and review of the implementation of the outcomes of the International Conferences on Financing for Development, including the Addis Ababa Action Agenda, and the delivery of the means of implementation of the 2030 Agenda.
Strategy
9.124	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:
(a)	Promote and support the follow-up to the agreements and commitments reached at the Fourth International Conference on Financing for Development;

(b)	Build on continuing analytical work in collaboration with the Inter-Agency Task Force on Financing for Development and prepare the annual Financing for Sustainable Development Report, and other reports for the Economic and Social Council forum on financing for development follow-up and for Second Committee and other deliberations;

(c)	Scale up investment for the Sustainable Development Goals with concrete solutions building on the work of the Global Investors for Sustainable Development Alliance and facilitate the dialogue on sustainable investment, including through the Sustainable Development Goals Investment Fair, enabling direct engagement between Member States and investors;

(d)	Provide policy support to intergovernmental processes and capacity-building to foster more inclusive and effective international tax cooperation; support Member States in enhancing tax policies and administration, improving domestic resource mobilization and addressing tax evasion, aggressive tax avoidance and illicit financial flows; and advance progress towards achieving the Sustainable Development Goals and climate action, focusing on countries in special situations;

(e)	Enhance support for the Development Cooperation Forum in its reviews of trends, progress and emerging issues in international development cooperation, focusing on policies and practices to support those with the fewest resources and the weakest capacities;

(f)	Support countries in designing and implementing integrated national financing frameworks, through the Integrated National Financing Framework Facility. The Facility, a joint initiative of the Department, the United Nations Development Programme, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, the United Nations Children’s Fund, the European Union and a few Member States, facilitates knowledge exchange and access to technical guidance on financing frameworks.
9.125	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	Policy and action on financing for sustainable development through strengthened analytical foundations for the outcomes of the Economic and Social Council forum on financing for development follow-up and Second Committee deliberations;
(b)	Countries designing and using integrated national financing frameworks, including actionable policy options, to mobilize financing for sustainable development;
(c)	Accelerated mobilization of resources for the Sustainable Development Goals, leading to greater investment opportunities with positive impacts, including in countries in special situations;

(d)	Improved solutions at all levels for strengthening international tax cooperation, improving domestic resource mobilization and more effective implementation by Governments and other stakeholders of United Nations policy and practical guidance on tax matters;

(e)	Utilization by Governments and other stakeholders of policy guidance to enhance international development cooperation, for the effective implementation of the 2030 Agenda, the Addis Ababa Action Agenda, the Paris Agreement and the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction 2015–2030.
Programme performance in 2024
Evidence-based intergovernmental preparations for the Fourth International Conference on Financing for Development

9.126	Substantive and evidence-based discussions are fundamental to informing the preparatory process of the Fourth International Conference on Financing for Development. The subprogramme has set up an “academic track” to systematically promote research, analysis and policy recommendations of academics and think tanks, which culminated in the “Financing for development dialogues: from evidence to action” conference that featured panel discussions on various topics. The conference enabled Member States and academia to deliberate and explore evidence-based solutions and innovative ideas for financing for development.
9.127	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 9.33).
Table 9.33 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Academics and think tanks engaged in financing for sustainable development deliberations in an ad hoc manner

Preparation for the Fourth International Conference on Financing for Development benefited from the analysis and recommendations of 400 members of academia and think tanks through the dedicated “academic track”

children.text: Result 2: strengthened engagement of Member States in the financing for development follow-up process to improve coherence and implementation of agreed outcomes – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

9.130	The subprogramme’s work contributed to strengthening the engagement of Member States in the financing for development process, with 102 countries participating in the intergovernmental follow-up, which exceeded the planned target of 95 countries.
9.131	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 9.X).
Figure 9.X – Performance measure: number of countries participating in the intergovernmental follow-up process to the international conferences on financing for development (annual)
Result 3: enhanced engagement of developing countries in shaping tax international norms – Proposed programme plan for 2026

9.132	The launch of negotiations towards a United Nations framework convention on international tax cooperation creates opportunities for universal participation in tax norm-setting, while many developing countries need enhanced support to effectively participate in this complex process. The subprogramme has provided integrated technical support and analysis, as well as capacity-building activities, enabling more developing countries to engage effectively in international tax discussions and strengthen the inclusiveness and effectiveness of international tax norms.
Lessons learned and planned change

9.133	The lesson for the subprogramme was the need for more targeted support to facilitate the effective participation of developing countries in international norm-setting processes, galvanizing their technical expertise in tax matters. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will implement a phased approach, establishing core capacity for immediate negotiation support needs, while gradually expanding integrated technical support to the Member State-led negotiations and targeted capacity-building to enhance countries’ engagement and their capabilities to shape international tax norms.
9.134	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 9.XI).
Figure 9.XI – Performance measure: number of developing countries engaging in shaping international tax norms (cumulative)

Explanation of variances by factor, component and subprogramme – Overall resource changes
Technical adjustments
9.139	As shown in table 9.39 (1), resource changes reflect a net decrease of $2,052,800, as follows:

(a)	Subprogramme 1, Intergovernmental support and coordination for sustainable development. The net increase of $119,600 relates to the higher provision at continuing vacancy rates for two posts (Programme Management Officer (P-3) and Research Assistant (General Service (Other level)) established in 2025 pursuant to Economic and Social Council decision 2024/342, which were subject to a 50 per cent vacancy rate in accordance with the established practice ($127,500), offset in part by the removal of non-recurrent provisions under furniture and equipment ($7,900) that were approved for 2025 pursuant to the same Council decision;

(b)	Subprogramme 2, Inclusive social development. The decrease of $587,400 relates to the removal of non-recurrent provisions under general temporary assistance, consultants, experts, travel of staff, contractual services, general operating expenses and supplies and materials that were approved for 2025 pursuant to General Assembly resolutions 78/172 and 78/318;

(c)	Subprogramme 3, Sustainable development. The decrease of $323,300 relates to the removal of non-recurrent provisions under general temporary assistance, consultants and experts that were approved for 2025 pursuant to General Assembly resolutions 78/317 and 79/1;

(d)	Subprogramme 4, Statistics. The decrease of $830,900 relates to the removal of non-recurrent provisions under general temporary assistance, consultants, experts, travel of staff and general operating expenses that were approved for 2025 pursuant to General Assembly resolutions 78/317, 78/322 and 79/1;

(e)	Subprogramme 6, Economic analysis and policy. The net decrease of $143,800 relates to the removal of non-recurrent provisions under general temporary assistance ($222,200) associated with the report of the Committee for Programme and Coordination (A/79/16), as endorsed by the General Assembly in its resolution 79/247, that were approved for 2025, and the removal of non-recurrent provisions under furniture and equipment ($3,900) that were approved for 2025 pursuant to Economic and Social Council resolution 2024/7, offset in part by the higher provision at continuing vacancy rates for one post of Economic Affairs Officer (P-3) established in 2025 pursuant to the same Council resolution, which was subject to a 50 per cent vacancy rate in accordance with the established practice ($82,300);

(f)	Subprogramme 9, Financing for sustainable development. The net decrease of $311,900 relates to the removal of non-recurrent provisions under consultants, contractual services, supplies and materials, and furniture and equipment that were approved for 2025 pursuant to General Assembly resolutions 78/231 and 79/235, offset in part by the adjustments for the higher provision for general temporary assistance positions pursuant to Assembly resolution 79/235;
(g)	Programme support. The increase of $24,900 relates to the higher provision for general temporary assistance positions pursuant to General Assembly resolution 79/235.
New and expanded mandates
9.140	As shown in table 9.39 (1), resource changes reflect an increase of $577,900, as follows:

(a)	Policymaking organs. The increase of $61,900 relates to the recurrent provision under travel of representatives for an additional 10 members of the Statistical Commission in 2026, pursuant to Economic and Social Council resolution 2024/2;

(b)	Subprogramme 3, Sustainable development. The increase of $58,200 relates to the non-recurrent provision under consultants to support the development and refinement of the handbook on vulnerability-resilience country profiles, pursuant to General Assembly resolution 78/322;

(c)	Subprogramme 4, Statistics. The increase of $457,800 relates to the non-recurrent provision under general temporary assistance for an Executive Secretary (P-5) and a Programme Management Officer (P-3) ($446,200) to support the work of the independent high-level expert group pursuant to General Assembly resolution 79/1, as well as for related travel of staff ($11,600) to present the work of the expert group.
Other changes
9.141	As reflected in table 9.39 (1), resource changes reflect a decrease of $341,100, as follows:

(a)	Subprogramme 1, Intergovernmental support and coordination for sustainable development. Cost-neutral changes relate to the proposed conversion of two long-term positions of Economic Affairs Officer (P-4 and P-3) from general temporary assistance to posts, in line with General Assembly resolution 79/257 of 24 December 2024, as described in annex II;

(b)	Subprogramme 4, Statistics. Cost-neutral changes relate to the proposed conversion of a long-term position of Statistician (P-4) from general temporary assistance to post, in line with General Assembly resolution 79/257 of 24 December 2024, as described in annex II;
(c)	Programme support. The decrease of $341,100 relates mainly to the lower standard price of the core software package at United Nations Headquarters under contractual services.
Extrabudgetary resources

9.142	As reflected in tables 9.39 (2) and 9.40 (2), extrabudgetary resources amount to $104,775,900. The resources would complement regular budget resources and would be used mainly to provide for various substantive and capacity development activities. Extrabudgetary estimates also include resources in the amount of $56,355,000 for the trust fund for the Junior Professional Officers Programme, which the Department administers (reflected under programme support).

9.143	Anticipated in-kind contributions will provide for donated right of use of premises for project offices with an estimated value of $406,000 ($204,000 under subprogramme 3, $158,000 under subprogramme 4 and $44,000 under subprogramme 7), and other services such as the provision of technical experts on a non-reimbursable loan basis, use of training facilities and provision of equipment, with an estimated value of $262,000 ($122,000 under subprogramme 3 and $140,000 under subprogramme 7).

9.144	The extrabudgetary resources under this section are subject to the oversight of the Under-Secretary-General for Economic and Social Affairs, who has delegated authority from the Secretary-General.
