children.text: 9.146	The proposed regular budget resources for 2026 amount to $2,144,900 and reflect an increase of $61,900 compared with the approved budget for 2025. The proposed change is explained in paragraph 9.140 (a). Additional details on the distribution of the proposed resources for 2026 are reflected in table 9.43.
Table 9.43
Policymaking organs: evolution of financial resources
(Thousands of United States dollars)
Executive direction and management

9.147	The Under-Secretary-General for Economic and Social Affairs is responsible for the overall management and administration of the Department in the effective implementation of its mandates and its approved programme of work, and the accountable use of the Department’s human, financial and physical resources. The Under-Secretary-General serves as the convener of the Executive Committee on Economic and Social Affairs; a member of the United Nations Sustainable Development Group; and Programme Manager of the United Nations Development Account, including capacity development activities. The Under-Secretary-General is assisted by the Assistant Secretary-General for Policy Coordination and the Assistant Secretary-General for Economic Development.

9.148	The Assistant Secretary-General for Policy Coordination supports the Under-Secretary-General by providing substantive policy advice on departmental support to intergovernmental processes, including the General Assembly, the Economic and Social Council and its subsidiary bodies, and the high-level political forum on sustainable development. The incumbent also supports the work of the United Nations Sustainable Development Group and the United Nations System Chief Executives Board for Coordination.

9.149	The Assistant Secretary-General for Economic Development serves as the principal economic adviser to the Under-Secretary-General and assists in providing thought leadership and guidance on the Department’s policy research and analysis work, including on frontier and emerging issues. The incumbent also coordinates and reviews the publications of the Department, reports of the Secretary-General and other technical products that amplify and deliver the work of the Department on global development policy.

9.150	Furthermore, the Assistant Secretaries-General are assigned responsibility for the substantive oversight and coordination of specific subprogrammes, within the authority delegated by the Under-Secretary-General, as reflected in the proposed organizational structure and post distribution for 2026 (see annex I).

9.151	The Office of the Under-Secretary-General supports the senior leadership in the overall coordination and management of its programmes and resources, the implementation of Department-wide initiatives and the overall programming, monitoring and evaluation activities. It also facilitates the work of the Department’s network of gender focal points and is responsible for the review of legislative reports and flagship publications of the Department.

9.152	Within the Office of the Under-Secretary-General are the Strategic Planning and Communications Service and the Programme, Monitoring and Evaluation Unit. The Strategic Planning and Communications Service supports the Under-Secretary-General in advancing the Department’s strategic direction, integration and policy coherence, including its collaborative work with other Secretariat entities in the areas of knowledge management, communications, websites, social and multimedia outreach, publishing and information technology. It supports the Department’s engagement in the Secretary-General’s Executive Committee and coordinating mechanisms or bodies and represents the Department in relevant Secretariat policy and normative bodies, including the Publications Board, the Information and Communications Technology Board and the United Nations Communications Group. It also supports the Department’s editorial board and departmental strategic planning and communications networks, as well as the implementation of the Department’s strategic communications framework.

9.153	The Programme, Monitoring and Evaluation Unit coordinates the preparation of the Department’s annual programme plan and is responsible for the internal monitoring and evaluation of the Department’s work. It supports evaluations and audits by oversight bodies. It also produces monitoring reports for senior management decision-making. The Unit operates independently from other operational and management functions within the Department.

9.154	In accordance with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, in particular target 12.6 of the Sustainable Development Goals, in which organizations are encouraged to integrate sustainability information into their reporting cycles, and in compliance with the cross-cutting mandate set out in paragraph 19 of General Assembly resolution 72/219, the Department is integrating environmental management practices into its operations. The Department uses online platform tools and organizes meetings and workshops in a virtual or hybrid format, whenever possible. In 2026, the Department will continue to encourage the electronic distribution of documents and materials, increase the paperless conduct of meetings and focus its efforts on the online readability of publications. Whenever supported by donors, the Department will offset the greenhouse gas emissions generated by air travel in connection with large-scale conferences.

9.155	Information on compliance with the timely submission of documentation and advance booking for air travel is reflected in table 9.44. The travel compliance improved in 2024 compared with that of 2023, although advance planning has remained challenging. The Department provided further internal guidance on the advance purchase policy after the revised administrative instructions on official travel were issued. The late receipt of voluntary contributions and late nominations of non-staff travellers continued to affect the rate of compliance. The Department will continue its efforts to improve the compliance rate by, among other efforts, promoting advance planning for all Department events and working more closely with Governments on the nominations of representatives. In 2024, the Department continued to submit nearly all its documents within the prescribed timelines.

Programme support
9.166	Programme support comprises the Executive Office and the Capacity Development Programme Management Office.

9.167	The Executive Office supports the Under-Secretary-General, as follows: (a) in his exercise of the delegation of authority to manage the human, financial and physical resources of the Department; (b) in the context of the monitoring and accountability framework; and (c) as his main interlocutor with the Department of Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance and the Department of Operational Support, including in relation to participation in focal point networks or committees in support of various management-related reform initiatives. The Executive Office also provides administrative support to other entities at Headquarters.

9.168	The Capacity Development Programme Management Office coordinates the Department’s capacity development functions by providing strategic guidance and coordination for the formulation and implementation of coherent and integrated capacity development activities. Such efforts support Member States in translating the outcomes of major United Nations conferences and intergovernmental processes into national strategies and plans. The Office manages both regular and extrabudgetary resources. It also promotes and supports strategic cooperation and partnerships within the Secretariat and with the broader United Nations development system, including the resident coordinator system, to ensure more coherent and integrated support for the implementation of the 2030 Agenda and the Addis Ababa Action Agenda at the country level. The Office supports the Under-Secretary-General in his role as Programme Manager of the United Nations Development Account. It also manages the Junior Professional Officers Programme for the Secretariat and the resident coordinator system.

table_content.text: Subprogramme 1, Intergovernmental support and coordination for sustainable development
Conversion of 2 Economic Affairs Officers from general temporary assistance to posts

The conversion has been proposed because the functions performed are of a continuing nature. The provision was first approved by the General Assembly in its resolution 68/246 and became effective in 2014 pursuant to Assembly resolution 67/226 on the quadrennial comprehensive policy review of operational activities for development of the United Nations system, and the functions have been carried out since then.

The proposed conversion would strengthen the subprogramme’s support for the continuous monitoring of and reporting by the Secretary-General on the funding and performance of the United Nations development system, with the most recent mandate reflected in Assembly resolution 79/226.

The incumbents undertake research and analysis on key trends and policy issues relating to operational activities for development; the design and evaluation of data to assess the funding, coherence, efficiency and effectiveness of operational activities for development; the establishment and growth of stakeholder relationships and networks on operational activities for development and implementation of quadrennial comprehensive policy reviews, including with inter-agency and intergovernmental bodies; and the production of reports to the Economic and Social Council and the General Assembly on the implementation of the quadrennial comprehensive policy review.
Subprogramme 1, Intergovernmental support and coordination for sustainable development
Reassignment of 1 Programme Management Officer as Information Systems Officer

The proposed reassignment is aimed at addressing the increased demand for awareness building, communications and stakeholder engagement and the improvement of the websites of the high-level political forum and the Economic and Social Council, as well as the non-governmental organizations platform. There is a significant need for an Information Systems Officer with the technical skills to develop, maintain and troubleshoot existing websites and platforms and computer information systems, so as to enhance those platforms and meet the growing demand for more secure, dynamic and accessible websites, which are critical to the delivery of the work of the subprogramme.
Conversion of 1 Statistician from general temporary assistance to post

The conversion has been proposed because of continuing need, although the functions performed have evolved over the years. The provision was first included under the subprogramme in 1998, as approved by the General Assembly in its resolution 52/220, to support the development of the United Nations Economic and Social Information System. The functions later evolved to support the Millenium Development Goals and, subsequently, the Sustainable Development Goals, through the continuous improvement and update of the database containing international data series for the monitoring and assessment of progress towards achieving the Goals.

The proposed conversion would enhance efficiency, streamline responsibilities and ensure the sustainability of key initiatives related to the United Nations World Data Forum, data stewardship, capacity development and global coordination efforts for data and statistics for the 2030 Agenda and the post-2030 Agenda.

The incumbent would support methodological work on data development, including data stewardship and data governance; the High-level Group for Partnership, Coordination and Capacity-Building for Statistics for the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development; and the organization of the United Nations World Data Forum.
